DataElement.preferredName: Progressive Recurrent Disease Assessment Method Malignant Tumor Type
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A response for the means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions performed in the final determination of progression or recurrence.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Progressive Disease Recurrent Disease Assessment Method
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A disease process that is increasing in scope or severity._The return of a disease after a period of remission._The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of._A means, manner of procedure, or systematic course of actions that have to be performed in order to accomplish a particular goal.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A disease process that is increasing in scope or severity.:The return of a disease after a period of remission.

Concepts.definition: A clinical, pathologic, and/or molecular finding indicating that the course of a disease is worsening in terms of extent or severity.
The return of a disease after a period of remission.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004_A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions._Having determined the value, significance, or extent of._Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.: An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence.: A facility equipped and competent to conduct scientific experiments, observations, tests, investigations, and/or to manufacture chemicals or medical products. : Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

Concepts.definition: One and the other; relating to or being two in conjunction.
Relating to the examination and treatment of patients dependent on direct observation.  The term may also refer to the institution (clinic) providing this activity.

A facility equipped and competent to conduct scientific experiments, observations, tests, investigations, and/or to manufacture chemicals or medical products.
Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A substance sometimes found in an increased amount in the blood, other body fluids, or tissues and which may mean that a certain type of cancer is in the body. Examples of tumor markers include CA 125 (ovarian cancer), CA 15-3 (breast cancer), CEA (ovarian, lung, breast, pancreas, and gastrointestinal tract cancers), and PSA (prostate cancer). Also called biomarker.

Concepts.definition: A substance present in or produced by a tumor or by the host, that can be used for differentiating neoplastic from normal tissue based on measurements in body fluids, secretions, cells, and/or tissues. Markers are used in diagnosis, staging and prognosis of cancer, provide an estimation of tumor burden, and serve for monitoring effects of therapy, detecting recurrence, localization of tumors, and screening in general populations.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An image produced on a radiosensitive surface by x-ray radiation that has penetrated and passed through a structure.

Concepts.definition: An image produced on a radiosensitive surface by x-ray radiation that has penetrated and passed through a structure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues.  Malignant neoplasms usually metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision.  The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin's and non-Hodgkin's lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas. -- 2004:A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions.:Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.:Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.
A practiced and regimented skill or series of actions.
The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.
Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.
